Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research Project: Effects of Scaffolding Cyber-Enabled Collaborative Learning in Authentic STEM Education Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jackson State University will investigate the effects of the proper levels of scaffolding for cyber-enabled collaborative learning on academic performance and skill development of African American STEM students and identify social and cognitive factors that can contribute to their achievement gains through cyber-enabled collaborative learning. The PIs will test the hypothesis that scaffolding cyber-enabled collaborative learning can promote shared construction of knowledge and regulation of learning processes for African American students and, thus, lead to improvement of their deeper understanding of important concepts and higher-order skill development.

The project will expand the current knowledge about cyber-enabled collaborative learning by conducting the research in a STEM context, particularly examining the effects of instructional guides in an authentic STEM education setting for African American students. Prior research on collaborative learning was conducted mainly on K-12 students or liberal arts college students. The study could add new perspectives in instructional strategies for STEM faculty to increase student engagement and persistence and improve academic performance in STEM and non-STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research is to investigate the effects of the proper levels of scaffolding for cyber-enabled collaborative learning on academic performance and skill development of students in their STEM learning. The project tests the hypothesis that scaffolding for cyber-enabled collaborative learning could promote shared construction of knowledge and regulation of learning processes for students, and lead to improvement of their deeper understanding of important concepts and higher-order skills. Through the collaboration among STEM faculty members and researcher from learning science, the project team has developed (1) develop the scaffolding based on the social and cognitive model and adopt the computer-supported learning system for facilitating online discussion; (2) integrated the scaffolding into collaborative learning assignments for student teams in multiple STEM courses; and (3) investigated their effects on students’ learning processes and outcomes. 


The research participants were undergraduate students in several STEM courses. As a part of course assignments, students in each participating course were assigned with collaborative learning tasks for selected specific learning concepts and problems. All students in each class were randomly assigned into four-member teams and all teams were randomly assigned into four different groups. There is the control group A, in which students received collaborative learning requirements only. Among three intervention groups, students of group B received the scaffolding of social interaction prompts, students of group C received the scaffolding of cognitive process prompts, and students of group D received the scaffolding of both social interaction prompts and cognitive process prompts. 


Social scaffolding was intended to guide student team members to engage in task-related social interactions. Under the social scaffolding, team members were required to play one of four roles in turn. These roles included the questioner offering questions and presenting her/his understanding about the learning task, the explainer responding to the posed questions and fact-checking the understanding presented by the questioner, the prompter reviewing the presented questions and answers as well as reminding peers to properly apply the provided prompts to organize their questions and answers, and the commentator examining viewpoints from both the questioner and explainer, commenting on the presented answers, and summarizing the discussion. Besides, the social scaffolding also included social interaction-oriented prompts provided to students through both the online system and collaborative learning assignments before the beginning of CSCL to help students produce thought-provoking questions for online discussions. The goal of cognitive scaffolding was to facilitate students’ cognitive processes for knowledge construction. The cognitive scaffolding is composed of question prompts or hints on concepts and problem-solving procedures specifically pertinent to the assigned collaborative learning tasks to guide students’ cognitive processes. These question prompts were to facilitate students’ constructions of the problem space, conceptual space, and relations between the conceptual and problem spaces.


The research adopts the advanced analytics approach, the Structure Equation Model (SEM) method, to establish multi-layer causal models for effectively revealing the effects of scaffolding for CSCL, given that other relevant learning variables may jointly impact the targeted learning outcomes. Besides, the research also reveals and discusses the advantages of SEM over the drawbacks of the simple statistical analysis method and MLR method. 


The established SEMs reveal that the social scaffolding may have a positive effect on students’ academic performance through CSCL, particularly for those students who has less participation at the initial stage of CSCL, while the cognitive scaffolding in the context of CSCL may have varied effects on learning outcomes for different students and thus may have to be provided in a more adaptive and personalized way. Nevertheless, the SEMs also indicate that the initial attitude and the prior academic achievement have even larger positive impacts on students’ academic performance than the social scaffolding for CSCL. If these learning variables cannot be equally distributed among the control and intervention groups, the simple statistical comparison of students’ academic performance in these groups may lead to incorrect conclusions on the effect of the intervention.


When the Mutiple Linear Regression (MLR) model includes all impacting variables as input variables the same as these input variables for the SEMs, the MLR model may lead to similar results as these from the SEMs. However, if other important impacting factors, such as the initial attitude and initial participation, are not considered as input variables for the MLR model, the MLR model may or may not identify the effects of intervention on the examined learning outcomes with statistical significance.


Furthermore, the simple statistical analysis method only examines the learning gains without considering the import impacting variables as input variables. The simple statistical comparison of students’ learning gains may lead to incorrect conclusions on the effect of the intervention due to the limitations of the simple statistical analysis, even though the SEM or MLR analysis of the same dataset indicates the positive effects of the intervention on the examined learning outcomes.
